questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Pyruvate carboxylase

B. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxy kinase

C. Hexokinase

D. Pyruvate kinase

E. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A and E only

 

Gluconeogenesis bypasses the three irreversible steps of glycolysis using four specific enzymes. From the given options, only two are actual gluconeogenic enzymes. Pyruvate carboxylase converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate in the mitochondria, requiring ATP and biotin as cofactor. This is the first step in bypassing the pyruvate kinase reaction. Glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes the final step, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose, which allows glucose release from liver and kidney cells. This enzyme is absent in muscle, explaining why muscle cannot contribute glucose to the bloodstream despite having glycogen stores.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (A, B and E only): "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" is not a real enzyme - this appears to be a nomenclature error. The actual gluconeogenic enzyme is phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK), which converts oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

 

Option B (B and C only): Neither enzyme participates in gluconeogenesis. "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" doesn't exist, and hexokinase catalyzes the forward glycolytic reaction (glucose → glucose-6-phosphate), consuming ATP rather than producing glucose.

 

Option D (A, B and C only): This includes both the non-existent "phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" and hexokinase, which is a glycolytic enzyme that would oppose gluconeogenesis by converting free glucose back to glucose-6-phosphate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among the listed enzymes, only pyruvate carboxylase and glucose-6-phosphatase are genuine gluconeogenic enzymes that help bypass the irreversible steps of glycolysis to synthesize glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors.

questions.text: Enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

 

Glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate back to glucose. It is activated when the insulin-to-glucagon ratio decreases. This enzyme plays a crucial role in gluconeogenesis, the process of synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources when blood glucose levels are low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucokinase: Glucokinase is an enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is primarily found in the liver and pancreatic beta cells. Glucokinase's activity is influenced by glucose levels, not the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Option B. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is another enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is present in various tissues, but its activity is not directly regulated by changes in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio's

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase (PFK): Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that converts glucose to pyruvate. It plays a role in glucose metabolism but is not activated by a decrease in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low insulin glucagon ratio means it is fasting state, as in fed state insulin is more. So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis, which occurs during fasting.
  • Phosphofructokinase is involved in glycolysis. PFK-1 is active in any situation and PFK-2 is active only in fed state.
  • Glucokinase phosphorylates glucose in liver and pancreas, active in fed state and is induced by insulin.
  • Hexokinase also phosphorylates glucose and is present in all cells of the body. It is active in any situation in body as it is a general enzyme to phosphorylate glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 137-138

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

 

The test used for the detection of ketone bodies (KB) in the given scenario of a 15-year-old boy with type I diabetes mellitus is Rothera's Test.

 

Rothera's Test involves the reaction of acetoacetate with sodium nitroprusside and glycine in an alkaline medium. This reaction forms a purple-colored complex, indicating the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of reducing sugars, such as glucose, in a solution.

 

Option C. Seliwanoff's test is used to differentiate between different types of sugars, particularly distinguishing ketoses from aldoses.

 

Option D. Biuret test The Biuret test is used to detect the presence of proteins in a sample by reacting with peptide bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.

 

In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.

questions.text: Transparency of corneal endothelium is maintained by: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratan sulphate

 

  • Keratan sulfate is a key glycosaminoglycan present in the corneal endothelium. It plays a significant role in maintaining corneal transparency by regulating hydration, contributing to the structural integrity of the cornea, and preventing swelling, which could impair vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparan sulfate: Heparan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in the cornea, but its main role is in the basement membrane and Bowman's membrane, rather than the corneal endothelium. It plays a role in supporting the structure but is not the primary factor for endothelial transparency.

 

Option C. Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another glycosaminoglycan found in the cornea, but its primary role is not related to endothelial transparency. It contributes to the overall structure and function of the cornea but does not play a direct role in maintaining endothelial clarity.

 

Option D. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid is essential for regulating hydration within the cornea, but its main role is in the corneal stroma, not the endothelium. It ensures the cornea remains transparent by preventing excessive swelling in the stromal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 602

questions.text: A 45-year-old vegetarian patient recovering from COVID-19 at home developed progressive weakness, fatigue, and tingling sensations in hands and feet. He mentions avoiding all supplements during recovery due to fear of overdose. His diet mainly consisted of plain rice and boiled vegetables for the past 3 months. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for his symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Explanation: 

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is the correct answer. In this case, the patient's strict vegetarian diet without supplementation, combined with possible COVID-related reduced absorption, puts them at high risk for B12 deficiency. B12 deficiency commonly presents with:

  • Peripheral neuropathy (tingling sensations)
  • Progressive weakness and fatigue
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Cognitive symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D deficiency: While common in COVID patients, Vitamin D deficiency primarily presents with bone pain, muscle weakness, and increased risk of fractures. It doesn't typically cause peripheral neuropathy as the primary symptom.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 deficiency: While B6 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy, it's relatively rare in developed countries and usually requires severe malnutrition. The symptoms are usually less prominent than B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 deficiency: Niacin deficiency (pellagra) presents with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While neurological symptoms can occur, peripheral neuropathy is not a prominent feature.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

B12 deficiency is common in:

  1. Strict vegetarians/vegans
  2. Malabsorption conditions
  3. Post-viral states affecting absorption
  4. Elderly patients
  5. Those with pernicious anemia

 

Early recognition is crucial as prolonged deficiency can cause irreversible neurological damage. Treatment requires supplementation, with initial parenteral therapy often needed in severe cases.

 

Normal serum B12 levels are 200-900 pg/mL, with deficiency typically diagnosed at levels below 200 pg/mL. The recommended daily allowance is 2.4 mcg/day for adults.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies is associated with sexual maturation defect and hypogonadism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zn (Zinc)

 

Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a critical role in numerous biological functions, including growth, immune function, and reproduction. Zinc deficiency is associated with several clinical manifestations, among which hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation are prominent. Hypogonadism refers to a condition where the body does not produce enough sex hormones, which can lead to delayed puberty, underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics, and infertility.

 

The deficiency of zinc impairs the normal functioning of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to decreased production of testosterone in males and estrogen in females. This hormonal imbalance is directly linked to the symptoms of sexual maturation defects observed in zinc-deficient individuals.

 

Zinc also plays a significant role in wound healing, immune function, and DNA synthesis. Its deficiency can lead to delayed wound healing, impaired immune response, and chronic diarrhea, further exacerbating the clinical picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Selenium deficiency is primarily associated with oxidative stress-related conditions, such as Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy). It is not typically associated with hypogonadism or sexual maturation defects.

 

Option C. Cu (Copper): Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia, and neurological issues but is not linked with hypogonadism or delayed sexual maturation. Copper is involved in iron metabolism and the functioning of several enzymes but does not directly impact the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron deficiency is well-known for causing anemia, particularly microcytic hypochromic anemia, and can lead to symptoms such as fatigue and weakness. While severe iron deficiency can impact overall growth and development, it is not specifically associated with hypogonadism or sexual maturation defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is directly linked to hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation, along with other symptoms such as impaired wound healing, decreased immunity, and chronic diarrhea. Recognizing and correcting zinc deficiency is crucial for preventing these clinical outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase 1

 

Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis that catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. Its activity is increased in the fed state and decreased during fasting. During fasting, the body's metabolic state shifts to prioritize gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation, leading to a decrease in glycolytic enzyme activities, including PFK-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormone-sensitive lipase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Mobilizes fatty acids from adipose tissue by breaking down triglycerides.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in the liver and muscles, providing glucose during fasting.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, a key step in gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

 

The correct answer is Glycosylation. Glycosylation is a process where sugars are added to proteins or lipids, but it occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, primarily during and after translation, not during post-transcriptional modifications. Post-transcriptional modifications occur to RNA molecules after they have been transcribed from DNA but before they are translated into proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation in the context of RNA processing involves the addition of a methyl group, often to the 5' end of the RNA as part of the capping process. For example, a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end of the RNA to protect it from degradation and assist in ribosome binding during translation.

 

Option B. Endonuclease cleavage: This is part of the splicing process where introns are removed from the pre-mRNA. Endonucleases cut within the nucleotide sequence, helping to remove non-coding sequences (introns) from the RNA transcript.

 

Option C. Capping: This process involves adding a modified guanine nucleotide (7-methylguanosine) to the 5' end of the RNA. This cap protects the RNA from degradation and is essential for the initiation of translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycosylation is not a post-transcriptional modification. Post-transcriptional modifications include processes like capping, methylation, and splicing, which are critical for the maturation of mRNA before it is translated into protein.

questions.text: Under anaerobic metabolism which of the following substrates yields 3 molecules of ATP? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycogen

 

Breakdown of glycogen yields glucose-6-phosphate which can enter the glycolysis pathway bypassing the first step thus saving one ATP and producing 3 ATPs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amino acid: Amino acids are not directly involved in anaerobic glycolysis and do not yield ATP through this pathway.

 

Option C. Glucose: The glycolysis of one glucose molecule under anaerobic conditions yields a net gain of 2 ATP molecules, not 3, because the initial phosphorylation step consumes one ATP.

 

Option D. Galactose: Galactose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate, but this conversion involves steps that consume ATP, resulting in a net gain similar to that of glucose, which is 2 ATP molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under anaerobic conditions, glycogen yields 3 molecules of ATP per glucose unit because it enters glycolysis as glucose-6-phosphate, bypassing the initial ATP-consuming step of glycolysis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient who is used to taking alcohol for the last 25 years suddenly presented with agitation and confusion. There were gait abnormalities. On enquiry, the person gave a history of alcohol withdrawal for 3 days. Identify the condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delirium tremens

 

The scenario described is most consistent with delirium tremens (DTs), a severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. DTs usually occur 2-3 days after cessation of heavy, prolonged alcohol consumption and can include symptoms such as agitation, confusion, tremors, hallucinations, and autonomic hyperactivity. The patient’s history of chronic alcohol use, coupled with recent withdrawal, supports this diagnosis. Gait abnormalities, confusion, and agitation are hallmark symptoms in this context.

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, often due to thiamine deficiency, presents with a classic triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (mnemonic "GOA"). However, the absence of ophthalmoplegia and the presence of withdrawal symptoms make delirium tremens a more fitting diagnosis in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine deficiency: Thiamine deficiency can lead to Wernicke’s encephalopathy, which presents with global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. However, the history of alcohol withdrawal and the symptoms presented align more with delirium tremens.

 

Option C. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as visual disturbances, metabolic acidosis, and neurological deficits, which are not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Ethanol poisoning: Ethanol poisoning usually presents with signs of intoxication, such as slurred speech, incoordination, and respiratory depression. This does not align with the history of withdrawal and the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium tremens is a life-threatening condition that occurs during alcohol withdrawal, characterized by confusion, agitation, tremors, and often hallucinations

choices.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid

 

Refsum's disease is a peroxisomal disorder caused by the impaired alpha-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, which results in the buildup of phytanic acid in the body. This accumulation of phytanic acid is a characteristic feature of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Beta oxidation is a different metabolic process.

 

Option C. Omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Omega oxidation is a different metabolic pathway.

 

Option D. Alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids: Refsum's disease primarily involves the defect in the alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, not the alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:

 

  • No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways
  • H2O2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase.
  • Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:

1. α-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA)

2. Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA)

 

Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in α-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.

  • Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid
  • In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
You are expected to produce a protein of interest. Arrange the following steps in a sequence.

 

  1. Lysis of bacterial cell
  2. Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria
  3. SDS-PAGE
  4. Hybridization
  5. Protein elution/extraction
  6. Expression of protein

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) b-f-a-c-d-e

 

Explanation:

 

The steps of Recombinant DNA technology for expressing a gene of interest for production of a desired protein in E. coli cell.

 

The steps of Recombinant DNA technology are:

 

  1. b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria: The gene of interest is inserted into a vector such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into the host E. coli cell to produce recombinant E. coli.
  2. f) Expression of protein: The recombinant E. coli is grown in a suitable medium to express the protein inside the cells.
  3. a) Lysis of bacterial cell: The bacterial cells are lysed to extract the expressed protein.
  4. c) SDS-PAGE: The extracted protein is purified using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis.
  5. d) Hybridization: The protein is identified and confirmed by western blotting or hybridization.
  6. e) Protein elution/extraction: Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted for subsequent use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

References: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 432-438

questions.text: What components constitute the backbone of a DNA molecule?(NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alternating phosphate and sugar groups

 

Explanation:

 

The DNA molecule has a backbone made up of alternating deoxyribose sugar and phosphate groups connected by 3',5'-phosphodiester bonds. This structure creates the "backbone" of DNA, while the nitrogenous bases (A, T, G, C) project inward from this backbone and form the base pairs that constitute the genetic information. The phosphodiester bonds connecting the sugar-phosphate backbone give DNA its directional nature, with one end having a 5' phosphate and the other having a 3' hydroxyl group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alternating sugars and nitrogenous bases: Incorrect because nitrogenous bases are not part of the backbone but rather project inward to form base pairs between the two strands of DNA.

 

Option B. Nitrogenous bases alone: Incorrect because bases are attached to the sugar components of the backbone via N-glycosidic bonds but do not themselves form the backbone structure.

 

Option C. Phosphate groups alone: Incorrect because phosphate groups alternate with deoxyribose sugar molecules to form the backbone; phosphates alone would not create the required structure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The DNA backbone consists of alternating deoxyribose sugar and phosphate groups connected by 3',5'-phosphodiester bonds, which forms the structural framework of the double helix while the nitrogenous bases attached to the sugars encode the genetic information.

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase is inhibited by all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methane

 

  • Methane does not inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
  • Cytochrome C oxidase is primarily inhibited by substances that interfere with the electron transport chain, such as cyanide and carbon monoxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H2S (Hydrogen Sulfide):

  • H2S can inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It is a known inhibitor of this enzyme and can disrupt mitochondrial respiration.

 

Option C. CO (Carbon Monoxide):

  • CO is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It binds to the same heme groups in the enzyme's active site as oxygen, preventing oxygen from binding and disrupting electron transport.

 

Option D. Cyanide:

  • Cyanide is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It binds to the iron in the enzyme's heme groups, blocking the transfer of electrons in the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CN, CO and H2S are inhibitors of Cytochrome c Oxidase (Complex IV of ETC). They inhibit by non-competitive inhibition and this type of inhibition is mostly irreversible. For a complete list of ETC inhibitors refer to table below:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 123

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

 

This is the correct answer. Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by cherry red spots on the retina, which are a distinctive sign of the condition. It is also associated with mental retardation and neurological symptoms. Tay-Sachs is a rare genetic disorder that affects the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a typical feature of Gaucher's disease. Gaucher's disease primarily affects the spleen, liver, and bone marrow, leading to symptoms such as anemia, enlarged liver and spleen, and bone pain.

 

Option C. Hunter Syndrome: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a common feature of Hunter syndrome. Hunter syndrome primarily affects connective tissues and leads to symptoms such as joint stiffness and organ enlargement.

 

Option D. Krabbe’s Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not typically seen in Krabbe disease. Krabbe disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and leads to symptoms like muscle weakness and developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: Lactulose is ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose and fructose

 

Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide used primarily as a laxative and in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It is composed of:

 

  • Galactose: A monosaccharide commonly found in dairy products.
  • Fructose: A monosaccharide found in many plants, where it is often bonded to glucose to form the disaccharide sucrose.

 

Lactulose is different from lactose, which is a natural disaccharide found in milk and composed of galactose and glucose.

 

Comparison with Other Disaccharides:

  • Lactose: Galactose + Glucose (found in milk, with a beta bond)
  • Maltose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,4 bond)
  • Isomaltose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,6 bond)
  • Trehalose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,1 bond)
  • Sucrose: Glucose + Fructose (table sugar, with an alpha bond)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactulose is composed of galactose and fructose, differentiating it from lactose, which is made up of galactose and glucose. It is commonly used for its medicinal properties, particularly as a laxative.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best screening investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry

  • Two mass spectrometers (MS) are arranged sequentially.
  • The first MS separates big peptides, based on their mass.
  • From this observation, a single peptide can be directed into the second MS (called parent ion or precursor ion). The parent ion enters the collision cell of the second MS. Here the ions collide with argon gas molecules and are broken into smaller ions. These daughter ions (product ions) are detected and quantified by their mass spectrum in the second instrument.
  • The high selectivity of MS-MS is that the parent ion mass and daughter ion mass are used for characterization.
  • The applications of MS-MS include:
    • Identification and quantification of proteins
    • Drug screening
    • Pesticides
    • Pollutants
    • Screening of inborn errors of metabolism, especially organic acidurias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Function: Used for detecting specific proteins in a sample using antibody binding.
  • Limitation: Not suitable for broad metabolic disorder screening; used for protein analysis.

 

Option C. PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction):

  • Function: Amplifies DNA sequences for genetic analysis.
  • Limitation: Highly specific for known genetic mutations; not suitable for comprehensive metabolic screening.

 

Option D. Gel electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates molecules (DNA, RNA, proteins) based on size and charge.
  • Limitation: Not specific or sensitive enough for broad metabolic disorder screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred method for screening metabolic disorders due to its ability to simultaneously analyze multiple metabolites with high sensitivity and specificity.

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
﻿﻿﻿The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
﻿﻿﻿The compound has three ionisable side chains
﻿﻿﻿The compound has one ionisable group

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

 

The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B, which corresponds to the pk1, and pk2 of the compound.

 

The above graph resembles the titration curve of the amino acid glycine.

 

Titration curve of Glycine:

 

 

The titration is completed at a pH of 12, where the glycine predominantly exists in the form of H2N - CH2 - COO.

 

pK1, and pK2, correspond to the point where the buffering capacity is maximum.

 

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • ﻿﻿Buffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the amino acid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • ﻿﻿An ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • ﻿﻿During the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • ﻿﻿Each of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • ﻿﻿The presence of two pKs indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • ﻿﻿The presence of three or more pKs indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • ﻿﻿Ex. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group: Points A and B represent the pKa values, not the range of maximum ionization. The range of maximum ionization would be broader than just the pKa points.

 

Option C. The compound has three ionisable side chains: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups. A compound with three ionizable groups would have three pKa values.

 

Option D. The compound has one ionisable group: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups (an amino group and a carboxyl group).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The points A and B on the titration curve represent the maximum buffering capacity of the compound, corresponding to the pKa values of the ionizable groups. The graph shown likely represents an amino acid like glycine, which has two ionizable groups.

questions.text: Which of the following can be mediated by CRISPR CAS 9 technology? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA editing

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is a powerful tool used for DNA editing. It works by creating double-strand breaks in the DNA at specific locations. The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats) component guides the Cas9 endonuclease to the precise cutting site within the genome. Once the DNA is cut, the cell’s natural repair mechanisms are used to add, delete, or replace genetic material at the targeted site, enabling precise editing of the DNA sequence.

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is derived from a natural immune system in bacteria, which uses this mechanism to defend against bacteriophages by cutting their DNA. In genetic engineering, this system has been harnessed for various applications, including gene deletion, exogenous gene insertion, and multigene editing, all of which involve altering the DNA sequence in a targeted manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA replication: CRISPR-Cas9 does not play a role in DNA replication, which is the process by which DNA is copied before cell division. DNA replication is managed by other cellular machinery, including DNA polymerases.

 

Option B. Post-transcriptional modification: This involves changes to RNA after it has been transcribed from DNA, such as splicing, editing, or polyadenylation. CRISPR-Cas9 does not mediate these processes; it specifically targets DNA.

 

Option C. DNA induction: This term is not commonly used in the context of molecular biology, and it does not apply to CRISPR-Cas9 technology. CRISPR-Cas9 is specifically used for editing DNA, not for inducing or initiating processes within the DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is primarily used for precise DNA editing, enabling targeted modifications to the genetic code

questions.text: During prolonged fasting, a patient's muscles break down proteins for gluconeogenesis, producing significant amounts of ammonia. Which amino acid primarily transports this ammonia from muscle to liver? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alanine

 

Explanation: 

 

Alanine is the correct answer. During fasting or exercise, muscle protein breakdown produces significant ammonia. The glucose-alanine cycle is the primary pathway for transporting this ammonia from muscle to liver because:

  • Pyruvate accepts amino groups to form alanine in muscle
  • Alanine safely carries nitrogen to liver
  • In liver, alanine is deaminated to produce pyruvate for gluconeogenesis
  • The released ammonia enters the urea cycle

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate participates in transamination reactions, it's not the primary carrier of ammonia from muscle to liver. It typically donates its amino group to form alanine in muscle.

 

Option D. Glutamine: Although glutamine is the primary carrier of ammonia from brain to liver, it's not the main transporter from muscle to liver. This role belongs to alanine through the glucose-alanine cycle.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine, while involved in one-carbon metabolism, does not play a significant role in ammonia transport from muscle to liver.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Students should understand:

  1. The glucose-alanine cycle's role in: 
    • Ammonia transport from muscle
    • Gluconeogenic substrate provision
    • Muscle protein catabolism during fasting
  2. Tissue-specific differences in ammonia transport: 
    • Brain → Liver: Glutamine pathway
    • Muscle → Liver: Alanine cycle
  3. Integration of amino acid metabolism with: 
    • Glucose metabolism
    • Nitrogen disposal
    • Energy homeostasis during fasting

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione reductase

 

This is the correct answer. Glutathione reductase is an enzyme that contains FAD as a prosthetic group and plays a significant role in the reduction of glutathione disulfide (GSSG) to glutathione (GSH). The activity of glutathione reductase, which depends on the availability of FAD, can be used to assess tissue riboflavin (FAD precursor) status. Therefore, measuring the activity of glutathione reductase with and without FAD is a method for assessing FAD status in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is not directly involved in determining FAD status. Thiamine plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism but doesn't directly influence the levels of FAD in the body.

 

Option C. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is an enzyme involved in the first step of glucose metabolism, but it is not responsible for determining FAD status.

 

Option D. Transketolase: Transketolase is marker enzyme for B1 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FAD is the active form of Vitamin B2 and marker for the B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 534

questions.text: Best method for detection of chromosomal translocations in leukemia is? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FISH

 

Explanation:

 

Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for detecting chromosomal translocations in leukemia. FISH provides direct visualization of specific chromosomal rearrangements using fluorescent-labeled probes that bind to specific DNA sequences, allowing detection of both numerical and structural chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Next-generation sequencing: While NGS can detect translocations, it requires complex bioinformatics analysis and may miss some structural variants. It's more suitable for comprehensive genomic profiling rather than rapid translocation detection.

 

Option C. Digital droplet PCR: Although highly sensitive for detecting point mutations and copy number variations, ddPCR requires prior knowledge of breakpoints and is not ideal for initial detection of chromosomal translocations.

 

Option D. Real-time PCR: While useful for quantifying specific known translocations, real-time PCR cannot detect novel or unexpected chromosomal rearrangements and requires prior knowledge of breakpoint sequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH advantages for translocation detection:

  • Direct visualization of chromosomal abnormalities
  • Can be performed on non-dividing cells
  • Rapid turnaround time
  • High sensitivity and specificity
  • Ability to detect cryptic translocations
  • Useful for monitoring disease progression
  • Can detect multiple abnormalities simultaneously

questions.text: The micronutrient deficient in a patient with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of skin and hair is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cu (Copper)

 

Copper deficiency can present with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of the skin and hair. Copper is a crucial cofactor for several enzymes, including tyrosinase, which is involved in the conversion of tyrosine to melanin, the pigment responsible for skin and hair color. When copper is deficient, melanin production decreases, leading to hypopigmentation. Additionally, copper plays a role in iron metabolism and immune function, which explains the anemia and neutropenia observed in copper deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zn (Zinc): Zinc deficiency is characterized by delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, hypogonadism, and diarrhea. While zinc is important for various enzymatic functions, it does not specifically cause hypopigmentation or the combination of anemia and neutropenia seen with copper deficiency.

 

Option B. Se (Selenium): Selenium deficiency is associated with Keshan disease, which primarily affects the heart and can lead to cardiomyopathy. Selenium plays a role in antioxidant protection but does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Fe (Iron): Iron deficiency primarily causes microcytic anemia, fatigue, and pallor. It does not lead to neutropenia or hypopigmentation of the skin and hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper deficiency is associated with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation due to its role in melanin synthesis and various other enzymatic processes.

choices.text: Causes the enzyme to work faster only

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding an allosteric modifier?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Participates in feedback regulation

 

This statement is generally true. Allosteric modifiers can play a role in feedback regulation, where the products of enzymatic reactions can act as allosteric modifiers to regulate the activity of enzymes in the same metabolic pathway. This helps maintain homeostasis in cellular processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desaturates the enzyme: This statement is not true. Allosteric modifiers do not desaturate enzymes. Instead, they can either activate or inhibit enzyme activity by binding to specific allosteric sites.

 

Option B. Causes the enzyme to work faster only: This statement is not entirely accurate. Allosteric modifiers can have both activating and inhibitory effects on enzyme activity. Some can enhance enzyme activity (activate), while others can decrease it (inhibit).

 

Option C. Binds to the catalytic site: This statement is not true for allosteric modifiers. Allosteric modifiers bind to allosteric sites, which are distinct from the catalytic site. The binding of an allosteric modifier at these sites can lead to conformational changes in the enzyme that affect its activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allosteric Regulation
 

  1. Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other).
  2. Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  3. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme (allosteric activation), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme (allosteric inhibition).
  4. In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier.
  5. The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity. If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity.
  6. In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.

questions.text: The enzyme that is not used in cholesterol synthesis? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HMG CoA lyase

 

Initially, acetoacetyl CoA is formed by condensation of two molecules of acetyl-CoA by cytosolic thiolase which then enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiolase: Thiolase is involved in the initial steps of cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option B. HMG CoA Reductase: HMG CoA reductase is a key enzyme in the cholesterol synthesis pathway.

 

Option C. HMG CoA Synthase: HMG CoA Synthase: HMG CoA synthase is involved in Both cholesterol synthesis and ketone body synthesis by forming HMG-CoA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

HMG CoA lyase is not used in the cholesterol synthesis pathway; it is involved in ketogenesis.

questions.text: A neonate on breast feeding develops jaundice. Urine Benedict’s test is positive. The enzyme deficiency is_________: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-P Uridyl Transferase

 

This is the enzyme deficient in classic galactosemia, a condition where galactose accumulates in the blood. This occurs because the neonate's diet (breast milk or formula) contains lactose, which is broken down into glucose and galactose. The inability to further metabolize galactose leads to its accumulation, causing symptoms like jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a positive Benedict's test (due to the presence of reducing sugars like galactose in the urine).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactokinase: While a deficiency in galactokinase can cause galactosemia, the clinical presentation is typically milder compared to galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency. Galactokinase deficiency usually leads to cataract formation due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye, but it doesn't typically cause severe jaundice or a positive Benedict's test, which indicates the presence of reducing sugars (like galactose) in urine.

 

 

Option C. Lactose: Lactose is a disaccharide composed of glucose and galactose, not an enzyme. Deficiency of lactase, the enzyme that breaks down lactose, leads to lactose intolerance, which typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, diarrhea, and gas, but not jaundice or a positive Benedict's test.

 

Option D. Aldolase B: Aldolase B deficiency leads to hereditary fructose intolerance. When fructose (from fruits, sweeteners, and some infant formulas) is ingested, it cannot be properly metabolized, leading to hypoglycemia and other symptoms. This condition does not lead to the accumulation of galactose, hence not causing the symptoms seen in this neonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neonate's symptoms, including jaundice and a positive Benedict's test for reducing sugars in the urine, are indicative of galactosemia. In galactosemia, there is a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, which is involved in the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate. Gal-1-P accumulates causes product inhibition of galactokinase resulting in galactose accumulation which comes out in urine giving positive Benedict’s test.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 198

questions.text: Which of the following are Methanol poisoning derivatives? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formic acid + Lactic acid

 

Methanol (CH3OH) is metabolized in the body by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase into formaldehyde (HCHO). This formaldehyde is further converted into formic acid (HCOOH), which is a primary toxic metabolite responsible for the harmful effects of methanol poisoning, including metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances, and organ damage.

 

Furthermore, formic acid inhibits the electron transport chain, particularly at complex IV (cytochrome C oxidase). This inhibition disrupts ATP production, leading to increased levels of NADH. Due to this blockage, pyruvate is converted to lactate, causing the accumulation of lactic acid, another metabolite associated with methanol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formic acid + Oxalic acid: Oxalic acid is not a metabolite of methanol poisoning but rather of ethylene glycol poisoning. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Option C. Glycolic acid and Oxalic acid: Both glycolic acid and oxalic acid are metabolites of ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. Hence, this choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Oxalic acid and Lactic acid: Oxalic acid is not a derivative of methanol poisoning; it is associated with ethylene glycol poisoning. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol poisoning primarily results in the formation of formic acid and lactic acid as toxic metabolites.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is not a feature of refeeding syndrome? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 


Refeeding syndrome occurs when a person who has been malnourished starts to eat again. This condition is characterized by metabolic and electrolyte imbalances caused by a sudden shift from a catabolic state (where the body breaks down tissue for energy) to an anabolic state (where the body builds tissue). When refeeding begins, there is an increase in glucose intake, which leads to increased insulin secretion.

 

Hyperkalemia is not a feature of refeeding syndrome. In fact, the opposite occurs (hypokalemia) due to the insulin-mediated intracellular shift of potassium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypophosphatemia: Insulin promotes the uptake of glucose and the subsequent metabolic processes that require phosphate. As phosphate is consumed in the generation of ATP and other metabolic pathways, its levels in the blood decrease, leading to hypophosphatemia.

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: Insulin also drives potassium into cells. As potassium moves intracellularly, the serum potassium levels drop, resulting in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypomagnesemia: Magnesium is a crucial cofactor for many enzymatic reactions, especially those involving ATP. As the metabolic rate increases, magnesium is used up, leading to hypomagnesemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Refeeding syndrome is characterized by hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia, not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: This child is suffering from: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kwashiorkor

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of malnutrition, primarily due to protein deficiency. It's characterized by edema, an enlarged liver, and often a distended abdomen, along with changes in hair and skin color. The presence of edema is a distinguishing feature from marasmus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marasmus: Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by energy deficiency. It typically presents with extreme muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat. Children with marasmus appear emaciated with very little muscle and fat tissue.

 

Option C. Von Gierke’s Disease: This is a type of glycogen storage disease caused by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase. It primarily affects the liver and kidneys, leading to symptoms like severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). It doesn't typically present with the same symptoms as malnutrition-related conditions like marasmus or kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Nephrotic Syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome is a kidney disorder that causes the body to excrete too much protein in the urine. Key features include severe edema, particularly around the eyes and in the lower extremities, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. While edema is present, it differs from the edema seen in kwashiorkor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake.
  • C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema (swollen belly and legs) due to decreased serum albumin levels.
  • Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.

 

Treatment – diet adequate in calories and protein.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 532-533

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency causes lactic acidosis due to inhibition of: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PDH (Pyruvate dehydrogenase)

 

Thiamine deficiency affects the activity of PDH, which is an enzyme complex responsible for converting pyruvate (a product of glycolysis) into acetyl-CoA, a key molecule in the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle). When PDH is inhibited, pyruvate cannot enter the citric acid cycle, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate, which is then converted to lactic acid, resulting in lactic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is not directly related to lactic acidosis in the context of thiamine deficiency. Its primary function is to catalyze the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which can be used in various metabolic pathways.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK): PEPCK is involved in gluconeogenesis, a metabolic pathway that synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. It does not directly contribute to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is an enzyme involved in the final step of glycolysis, where it catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not directly associated with lactic acidosis due to thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is the enzyme affected in a patient with thiamine deficiency who develops lactic acidosis.

 

 

Enzyme performing oxidative decarboxylation need vitamin B1 for their reaction. Some examples are:

  1. PDH
  2. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  3. Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Additional Information:

  • Marker for B1 deficiency is Transketolase activity
  • Coenzyme for simple decarboxylation: B6
  • Marker for B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity

questions.text: Which one of the following is not involved in iron metabolism? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transthyretin

 

Transthyretin is not involved in iron metabolism. It transports thyroxine.

 

Hepcidin, a 25-amino-acid (aa) peptide, is the principal regulator of iron absorption and its distribution to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceruloplasmin: Functions as a ferroxidase, converting Fe2+ (ferrous iron) to Fe3+ (ferric iron), which is essential for iron binding to transferrin for transport.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: A 25-amino-acid peptide that is the principal regulator of iron absorption and its distribution to tissues. It inhibits iron release from enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation.

 

Option D. Transferrin: The main iron transport protein in the blood. It binds and transports iron to various tissues, including the bone marrow for erythropoiesis and the liver for storage.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following are vitamin-B12 dependent enzymes? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Methylmalonyl Co isomerase
  2. Homocysteine synthase
  3. Folate reductase
  4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

 

Among the given enzymes, methyl malonyl Co isomerase and methionine synthase are vitamin B12 dependent enzymes.

 

Physiologic role of B12 –

 

  1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase: D-Methyl malonyl CoA is formed in the body from propionyl CoA. It is then converted to L form by a racemase and then isomerized by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (containing Ado-B12) to succinyl CoA, which enters into citric acid cycle. In B12 deficiency, methylmalonyl CoA accumulates and methyl malonic aciduria occurs.
  2. Homocysteine Methyl Transferase requires B12 activity to convert homocysteine to methionine.
  3. Methyl Folate Trap and Folate Deficiency - The production of methyl THFA is an irreversible step. Therefore, the only way for regeneration of free THFA is step No. 1 in Figure. When B12 is deficient, this reaction cannot take place. This is called the methyl folate trap. This leads to the associated folic acid scarcity in B12 deficiency.

 

 

Vitamin B12-dependent Enzymes:

 

1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase (Methylmalonyl CoA mutase): This enzyme converts methylmalonyl CoA to succinyl CoA, a critical step in the catabolism of certain amino acids and fatty acids. The enzyme requires adenosylcobalamin (Ado-B12) as a cofactor.

 

4. Methionine Synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine using methylcobalamin (Me-B12) as a cofactor. This reaction is crucial for the regeneration of methionine and the production of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), an essential methyl group donor in numerous methylation reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Homocysteine Synthase: There is no enzyme by this specific name, but homocysteine is converted to methionine by methionine synthase, which is vitamin B12-dependent.

 

3. Folate Reductase: This enzyme reduces dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF), an essential step in folate metabolism. However, it does not require vitamin B12 as a cofactor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enzymes methylmalonyl CoA isomerase and methionine synthase are dependent on vitamin B12. These enzymes play critical roles in metabolic pathways, including amino acid catabolism and methylation reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for using phenylbutyrate in urea cycle disorders? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It scavenges nitrogen

 

In urea cycle disorders ammonia cannot be converted to urea, but alternatively can be converted to glutamine and glycine. Ammonia scavengers phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate react with glutamine and glycine and consequently remove excess of ammonia. Phenylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in urine.

 

Phenylbutyrate is metabolized into phenylacetate, which conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. Similarly, sodium benzoate conjugates with glycine to form hippurate. Both phenylacetylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in the urine, thereby reducing the levels of ammonia in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It maintains renal output: While phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate are excreted in the urine, their primary function is not to maintain renal output but to remove excess ammonia.

 

Option C. It maintains energy production: Phenylbutyrate does not directly impact energy production. Its primary role is to help remove excess ammonia from the body.

 

Option D. It activates enzymes: Phenylbutyrate does not activate enzymes. Instead, it works by conjugating with amino acids to facilitate the removal of ammonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to scavenge nitrogen by reacting with glutamine, converting excess ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B deficiency

 

Vitamin B deficiency: This is the correct answer. The symptoms given in question are suggestive of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is caused by a deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine). Chronic alcoholism can lead to thiamine deficiency, which results in neurological symptoms like those described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A deficiency: Vitamin A deficiency typically presents with different symptoms, such as night blindness and skin issues, and is not related to the neurological symptoms seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to various bone related problems like Rickets and Osteomalacia, but it is not associated with the specific symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements seen in this case.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily presents with symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, and bleeding gums. It is not related to the neurological symptoms described in the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke encephalopathy – An acute, reversible but life-threatening condition. Clinical Vignette include Confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Nystagmus, Ataxia.

questions.text: A patient present with an X-ray showing cardiomegaly, along with symptoms of hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pompe's disease


Pompe's disease, also known as Type II glycogen storage disease, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (also known as alpha-glucosidase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen in the lysosomes. Without this enzyme, glycogen accumulates within the lysosomes, leading to lysosomal storage disease. The clinical features of Pompe's disease include cardiomegaly, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, macroglossia, and the characteristic "floppy baby" syndrome due to severe muscle weakness. The disease primarily affects the heart and skeletal muscles, often leading to heart failure as seen in the presented X-ray with cardiomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebstein anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect involving the tricuspid valve but does not present with hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, or the "floppy baby" syndrome seen in Pompe's disease. Ebstein anomaly primarily affects the heart, causing cyanosis and heart failure but lacks the systemic metabolic features of Pompe's.

 

Option C. Transposition of great arteries: This is another congenital heart defect characterized by the abnormal arrangement of the heart's major arteries. While it presents with severe cardiopulmonary symptoms such as cyanosis and heart failure, it does not cause hypotonia, macroglossia, or hepatomegaly, distinguishing it from Pompe's disease.

 

Option D.  Von Gierke's disease: Von Gierke's disease (Type I glycogen storage disease) affects liver metabolism, leading to severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, renomegaly, and metabolic derangements such as lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia. However, it does not involve cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, or "floppy baby" syndrome, making it an incorrect diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Pompe's disease is characterized by the combination of cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and macroglossia, often presenting as "floppy baby" syndrome due to lysosomal storage of glycogen.

questions.text: Common precursor amino acid for urea, creatine and nitric oxide is? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arginine

 

Arginine is the common precursor for urea, creatine and nitric oxide.

 

Arginine serves as the common precursor for all three compounds. It plays a central role in the urea cycle, where it is converted into ornithine, eventually leading to the production of urea. Additionally, arginine is a precursor for creatine synthesis, which is important for energy metabolism in muscles. It is also a precursor for nitric oxide, which has various physiological functions, including vasodilation and neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycine: Glycine is not the common precursor for these three compounds. It is involved in various metabolic pathways but not directly related to the synthesis of urea, creatine, or nitric oxide.

 

Option C. Aspartate: Aspartate is not the common precursor for urea, creatine, and nitric oxide. It is primarily involved in the urea cycle as a component of reactions leading to the synthesis of arginine and urea.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine is not the common precursor for these compounds. It has roles in various metabolic pathways, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of urea, creatine, or nitric oxide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ornithine and citrulline are derivatives of arginine, and are essential for urea synthesis.
  • Creatine is synthesized from 3 amino acids: glycine, arginine and methionine (GAME)
  • Arginine is the precursor of nitric oxide which is an important signal molecule in the body.

questions.text: Xanthurenic Acid in urine indicates: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6 deficiency

 

Xanthurenic assay a.k.a. Tryptophan load test. Xanthurenic acid in urine indicates Vitamin B6 deficiency. Xanthurenic acid is a metabolite that is formed during the breakdown of the amino acid tryptophan. Under normal conditions, tryptophan is metabolized along the kynurenine pathway, which involves the conversion of tryptophan to various intermediate compounds. One of these intermediates is xanthurenic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase activity, thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) effect, and blood thiamine levels.

 

Option C. Niacin deficiency: Measurement of urinary N-methylnicotinamide (NMN) excretion, and niacin load test.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with a deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), the conversion of tryptophan to niacin (vitamin B3) is impaired. As a result, tryptophan is metabolized through an alternative pathway, leading to the accumulation of xanthurenic acid. Therefore, the presence of xanthurenic acid in urine is indicative of a vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RT-PCR

 

  • RT-PCR is a molecular biology technique used to amplify and analyze RNA.
  • It involves the conversion of RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcription, followed by PCR amplification of the cDNA.
  • RT-PCR is specifically used for RNA analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Western blotting is a technique used to detect and analyze proteins.
  • It involves the separation of proteins by gel electrophoresis and their subsequent transfer to a membrane for detection using antibodies specific to the protein of interest.
  • Western blotting primarily deals with proteins, not RNA.

 

Option C. Sanger's method (Sanger Sequencing):

  • Sanger sequencing is a DNA sequencing technique developed by Frederick Sanger.
  • It is used to determine the nucleotide sequence of DNA strands.
  • Sanger sequencing deals with DNA, not RNA.

 

Option D. G-banding:

  • G-banding is a cytogenetic staining technique used to visualize and analyze the banding patterns of chromosomes.
  • It is used in karyotyping and primarily focuses on the visualization of chromosomal DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is a method for detection of gene expression using reverse transcription of RNA to synthesize cDNA. Western Blot most commonly involve antigen-antibody interactions which is a.protein-protein interaction. Sanger’s method is a DNA sequencing technique by chain termination of DNA polymerization using DNA as template. G-banding is a chromosomal staining technique usually done for karyotyping analysis and involve only DNA.

 

Ref- Lehninger 6th e/p 331

questions.text: Which of the following TCA cycle intermediate is a part of heme metabolism? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Succinyl CoA

 

TCA cycle is truly amphibolic (both catabolic and anabolic) in nature. Since various compounds enter into or leave from TCA cycle, it is sometimes called as “metabolic traffic circle”.

 

  • Succinyl CoA and Heme Synthesis:
    • Function: Succinyl CoA combines with glycine to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), which is the first step in the synthesis of heme.
    • Enzyme Involved: The enzyme ALA synthase catalyzes this reaction in the mitochondria.
    • Importance: Heme is a vital component of hemoglobin, myoglobin, and various cytochromes involved in electron transport and drug metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha Ketoglutarate:

  • Function: Precursor for the synthesis of glutamate and subsequently other amino acids.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Option B. Fumarate:

  • Function: Intermediate in the TCA cycle, involved in the conversion of fumarate to malate.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Option D. Malate:

  • Function: Intermediate in the TCA cycle, involved in the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate.
  • Relevance: Not directly involved in heme metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important anabolic reactions related with citric acid cycle are:

  1. Oxaloacetate is the precursor of aspartate
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate can be made into glutamate
  3. Succinyl CoA is used for synthesis of heme
  4. Mitochondrial citrate is transported to cytoplasm, where it is cleaved into acetyl CoA, which then is the starting point of fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following does not favor euchromatin formation due to changes occurring at Cytosine residues at Cp islands in DNA?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylation 

 

Euchromatin is a form of chromatin that is loosely packed and transcriptionally active, allowing for the expression of genes. The formation and maintenance of euchromatin are influenced by various post-translational modifications of DNA and histones.

 

Methylation of Cytosine Residues at CpG Islands:

 

  • CpG Islands: These are regions of DNA with a high frequency of CpG dinucleotides, often found near gene promoters and regulatory regions.
  • Methylation: The addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues in CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of heterochromatin (inactive, condensed chromatin). This methylation process hinders the binding of transcription factors and other regulatory proteins, leading to a more compact chromatin structure and reduced gene expression.
  • Impact on Euchromatin: Methylation of cytosine residues is a key epigenetic modification that does not favor euchromatin formation because it inactivates the DNA, leading to a transcriptionally inactive state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphorylation: Phosphorylation of histones can promote chromatin remodeling and gene expression, thus favoring euchromatin formation.

 

Option C. Alkylation: Alkylation typically refers to the addition of alkyl groups to DNA or histones, which can have varying effects. However, it does not specifically inhibit euchromatin formation in the way that methylation does.

 

Option D. Sumoylation: Sumoylation involves the addition of small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) proteins to histones or other proteins. This modification generally influences protein stability and function, but it does not directly interfere with euchromatin formation like methylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methylation of cytosine residues at CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of transcriptionally inactive heterochromatin, thus not favoring euchromatin formation.

questions.text: Which Glycogen Storage Disease listed below does not typically result in Hypoglycemia? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II (Pompe's Disease)

 

Explanation:

 

Type II glycogen storage disease (Pompe's disease) is characterized by deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase (acid α-glucosidase). Unlike the other listed disorders, Pompe's disease affects glycogen breakdown in lysosomes rather than in the cytosol. The disease primarily manifests with accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes of multiple tissues - especially heart, muscle, and brain - causing cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, and neurological symptoms. Pompe's disease does not typically present with hypoglycemia as the primary metabolic derangement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I (Von Gierke's Disease): This is incorrect because Von Gierke's disease, caused by glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, is characterized by severe hypoglycemia. The enzyme defect prevents the liver from releasing glucose into the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Type III (Cori's Disease): This is incorrect because Cori's disease (debranching enzyme deficiency) does present with hypoglycemia, although it's typically less severe than in Type I. Mild hypoglycemia or early morning hypoglycemia is a characteristic.

 

Option D. Type VI (Hers' Disease): This is incorrect because Hers' disease (liver phosphorylase deficiency) does present with hypoglycemia, although it's generally mild. Mild hypoglycemia is a feature of this disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pompe's disease (Type II GSD) affects lysosomal glycogen breakdown and primarily presents with cardiac, muscular, and neurological symptoms rather than hypoglycemia, which is a prominent feature of GSDs affecting hepatic glucose release (Types I, III, and VI).

questions.text: Apolipoprotein B 48 is a made of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA editing

 

 ApoB-48 is produced through RNA editing. RNA editing involves the modification of the nucleotide sequence of an RNA molecule, specifically the conversion of a cytosine (C) to a uracil (U) in the mRNA. In the case of ApoB-48, this editing changes a codon, resulting in the synthesis of a shorter protein product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA Alternate Splicing: RNA alternate splicing is a process where different exons (coding regions) of a pre-mRNA are combined in various ways to generate different mature mRNA molecules. This process can result in the production of different protein isoforms, but it is not the mechanism for generating ApoB-48.

 

Option C. DNA Editing: DNA editing typically refers to genetic engineering techniques that modify the DNA sequence, such as CRISPR-Cas9. This is not the process by which ApoB-48 is generated.

 

Option D. RNA Interference: RNA interference (RNAi) is a cellular process involved in gene regulation, where small RNA molecules inhibit gene expression. It does not play a direct role in the synthesis of ApoB-48.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In liver cell, Apo B100 gene gives rise to Apo B 100 protein. But Apo B48 protein is made in intestinal cells from the gene encoding Apo B100, by the process of RNA editing, which is also known as Differential RNA processing or chemical modification of RNA. This is a post transcriptional modification.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 238

questions.text: In Menke's disease, which of the following enzymes would be affected?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysyl oxidase

 

Lysyl oxidase is the enzyme affected in Menkes disease. Menkes disease is a genetic disorder that impairs copper absorption and transport, leading to a deficiency of copper-dependent enzymes like lysyl oxidase. Lysyl oxidase is crucial for the cross-linking of collagen and elastin fibers in connective tissues, and its deficiency results in connective tissue abnormalities seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysyl hydroxylase: Lysyl hydroxylase is not directly affected by Menkes disease. Lysyl hydroxylase is involved in the post-translational modification of collagen, and its dysfunction can lead to certain types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, not Menkes disease.

 

Option C. Prolyl oxidase: Prolyl oxidase is not directly associated with Menkes disease. It is involved in the formation of collagen cross-links but is not specifically affected in this condition.

 

Option D. Prolyl hydroxylase: Prolyl hydroxylase is not the enzyme affected by Menkes disease. It plays a role in collagen synthesis, but its deficiency is not a characteristic feature of Menkes disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke’s kinky hair syndrome is an x-linked defect (affects only male child). It is a condition in which dietary copper is absorbed from GI tract; but cannot be transported to blood due to absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase (mutation in ATP7A gene).

 

Copper is not mobilized from intestinal cells as well as in other tissue cells. The copper that has entered into the cell is not able to get out of the cells, and so it is accumulated. Hence, copper is not available for metabolism, resulting in defective cross-linking of connective tissue. Vascular and connective tissues are affected, and child dies usually in infancy. Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused by the defect of which of the following organelles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes

 

Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisome biogenesis disorder caused by defects in peroxisomes. Peroxisomes are essential organelles involved in various metabolic processes, and their dysfunction leads to Zellweger syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in mitochondria. Mitochondria are responsible for energy production in cells, and defects in mitochondria lead to different diseases, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lysosomes: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in lysosomes. Lysosomes are responsible for breaking down cellular waste and are associated with lysosomal storage disorders, which are different from peroxisomal disorders like Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Nucleus: Zellweger syndrome is not primarily caused by a defect in the nucleus. It is a peroxisomal disorder, and the genetic mutations associated with Zellweger syndrome typically affect genes related to peroxisome biogenesis, not nuclear genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Zellweger syndrome, there are empty peroxisomes in all body cells causing defect in alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA. So, both phytanic acid and VLCFA accumulate. It is the most severe Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorder (PBD).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis pathway? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palmitic acid

 

Palmitic acid is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a saturated fatty acid with 16 carbon atoms and is a major product of de novo fatty acid synthesis in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is not the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a polyunsaturated fatty acid that can be synthesized from linoleic acid, which is an essential fatty acid.

 

Option B. Oleic acid: Oleic acid is not the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a monounsaturated fatty acid that can be synthesized within the fatty acid synthesis pathway but is not the most common end product.

 

Option D. Acetyl CoA: Acetyl CoA is not an end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a starting substrate for fatty acid synthesis, as fatty acids are synthesized by adding two-carbon units (acetyl groups) to a growing fatty acid chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acids are synthesized from acetyl CoA mainly by a de novo synthetic pathway operating in the cytoplasm referred to as extramitochondrial or cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase system.

 

The major fatty acid synthesized de novo is palmitic acid, the 16C saturated fatty acid. The process occurs in liver, adipose tissue, kidney, brain, and mammary glands.

 

Beta oxidation of fatty acids breaks it down into Acetyl CoA.

 

 

Defect in pathway - Inhibition of lipogenesis occurs in type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes mellitus, and variations in its activity affect the nature and extent of obesity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old Mediterranean man has significantly lower rates of cardiovascular disease compared to his Western counterparts despite having similar risk factors. His diet is rich in olives and olive oil. Which fatty acid predominantly present in his diet is most likely responsible for the cardioprotective effect? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Omega 9 FA

 

Explanation: 

 

Omega-9 fatty acids (particularly oleic acid) are the correct answer. The Mediterranean diet, rich in olive oil, is associated with reduced cardiovascular risk primarily due to its high omega-9 content. Omega-9 fatty acids provide cardioprotection through:

  • Reducing LDL cholesterol levels
  • Increasing HDL cholesterol
  • Improving insulin sensitivity
  • Decreasing inflammation
  • Enhancing endothelial function

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saturated Fatty Acid: Saturated fatty acids are generally associated with increased cardiovascular risk due to their effects on raising LDL cholesterol and promoting inflammation. They are not cardioprotective.

 

Option B. Omega 3 FA: While omega-3 fatty acids are cardioprotective, they are not the predominant fatty acids in olive oil or the Mediterranean diet. They are more commonly found in fish and certain seeds.

 

Option C. Omega 6 FA: Though essential, excessive omega-6 fatty acids can promote inflammation when consumed in high ratios compared to omega-3. They are not the characteristic fatty acids of the Mediterranean diet.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Mediterranean diet's cardioprotective effects are attributed to:

  1. High monounsaturated fat (omega-9) content from olive oil
  2. Balanced omega-6:omega-3 ratio
  3. Low saturated fat intake
  4. Rich in polyphenols and antioxidants

 

Omega-9 fatty acids (oleic acid) constitute about 55-83% of olive oil composition. The recommended intake of monounsaturated fats should be 15-20% of total daily calories for cardiovascular benefits.

questions.text: The active site of enzyme is complimentary to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substrate
