The active site of an enzyme is complementary to the substrate. The active site is a specific region of the enzyme where the substrate binds, forming an enzyme-substrate complex. This binding is highly specific and is often likened to a lock-and-key or induced-fit model. It provides a specific environment that facilitates the conversion of substrate into product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition state: The transition state refers to the intermediate state of a substrate as it undergoes a reaction and transforms into a product. While enzymes stabilize the transition state during catalysis, the active site itself is typically complementary to the substrate, not the transition state.

 

Option B. Allosteric activator: Allosteric activators bind to allosteric sites on enzymes, which are distinct from the active site. Allosteric regulation involves a change in the enzyme's conformation, affecting its activity.

 

Option D. Product: The active site is not complementary to the product. Once the reaction occurs, the product is released from the active site, allowing the enzyme to participate in another catalytic cycle with a new substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of the active site of an enzyme and its relationship to substrates. The active site of an enzyme is complimentary to the substrate, allowing specific interactions that enable the enzyme to catalyze a particular chemical reaction. It stabilizes the transition state of the reaction, facilitating the conversion of substrates into products.

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Capping

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis.

 

Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

 

Note - Capping is done for mRNA (7-methyl guanosine cap) not DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mismatch repair: DNA methylation is involved in distinguishing parental DNA strands during the mismatch repair process.

 

Option B. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation plays a significant role in the remodeling of chromatin structure.

 

Option D. Gene silencing: DNA methylation is a key mechanism involved in the silencing of genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not related to RNA capping, which is an mRNA modification process. Instead, it is involved in processes such as mismatch repair, chromatin remodeling, and gene silencing.

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combination of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine – Transketolase

 

This is the correct combination. Consuming polished rice can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Transketolase is an enzyme involved in thiamine-dependent reactions, and its activity can be affected by thiamine deficiency, leading to various health issues, including beriberi, which is associated with thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin - Glutathione Reductase: This combination is not relevant to the consumption of polished rice. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and glutathione reductase is not directly related to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine - Transaminase: While thiamine deficiency can affect various enzymes, transaminase is not specifically associated with thiamine deficiency related to polished rice consumption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin - Transketolase: This combination is not relevant to polished rice consumption. Riboflavin deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and transketolase is not directly related to riboflavin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The consumption of polished rice leads to thiamine deficiency which leads to defective transketolase activity.

 

Polished rice undergoes milling, which removes the outer bran layer rich in B vitamins and other nutrients

questions.text: Methotrexate reduces the synthesis of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TMP

 

Methotrexate inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is crucial for the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from dihydrofolate. Tetrahydrofolate is required for the synthesis of thymidylate (TMP), as it acts as a one-carbon donor in the conversion of deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP) by thymidylate synthase. By inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, methotrexate indirectly reduces the availability of tetrahydrofolate, thereby decreasing the synthesis of TMP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GMP: Guanosine monophosphate (GMP) synthesis is not directly affected by methotrexate. GMP is a purine nucleotide, and its synthesis primarily involves different enzymes that are not dependent on thymidylate synthase or dihydrofolate reductase.

 

Option C. CMP: Cytidine monophosphate (CMP) synthesis involves pathways that are independent of tetrahydrofolate and thymidylate synthase, so methotrexate does not significantly impact its production.

 

Option D. AMP: Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) is another purine nucleotide whose synthesis does not involve dihydrofolate reductase or thymidylate synthase, so methotrexate does not directly affect its synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to reduced synthesis of TMP by limiting tetrahydrofolate availability.

questions.text: Most radio-resistant phase of cell cycle? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S

 

This is the synthesis phase, where DNA replication occurs. Cells in S phase are considered the most radio-resistant because they have already duplicated their genetic material, making them less susceptible to radiation-induced damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G1 (Gap 1) Phase: Cells in the G1 phase are generally sensitive to radiation because they are actively engaged in normal metabolic activities and are preparing for DNA synthesis in the subsequent S phase.

 

Option C. G2 (Gap 2) Phase: The G2 phase is a period of further preparation for cell division (mitosis). Quite radiosensitive, due to checkpoint activation.

 

Option D. M Phase (Mitosis): This is the phase where cell division occurs, and the cell divides into two daughter cells. Cells in M phase are most sensitive to radiation.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibitor in the graph?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive inhibitor

 

Explanation:

 

This is a Lineweaver-Burk plot of enzyme kinetics, with 1/v (inverse of velocity) on the Y-axis and 1/[S] (inverse of substrate concentration) on the X-axis. The red line represents the inhibitor, and the blue line represents the normal substrate.

 

In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, the Km (Michaelis constant) increases while the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged. This is evident in the graph where the slope increases, indicating an increased Km, but the Y-intercept, representing 1/Vmax, stays the same.

 

For non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km remains unchanged. This would be shown by an increase in the Y-intercept, which is not the case here.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibitor: In non-competitive inhibition, the Vmax decreases while the Km remains unchanged. This would be reflected in the graph by an increased Y-intercept (1/Vmax) while the slope remains the same, which is not observed here.

 

Option C. Allosteric inhibitor: Allosteric inhibitors bind to a site other than the active site and can either increase or decrease enzyme activity, affecting both Km and Vmax. The specific effects depend on the nature of the allosteric inhibition, which is not represented by the given Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibitor: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax. This would be shown by parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is not seen in the provided graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibitors increase the Km without affecting the Vmax, which is shown by an increase in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot without changing the Y-intercept.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 77

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are conjugated to the steroid nucleus of bile acids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycine and taurine

 

Explanation:

 

Bile acids, derived from cholesterol, are essential for the digestion and absorption of fats. The liver synthesizes two primary bile acids: cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid. These bile acids are then conjugated with the amino acids glycine or taurine to form bile salts, which are more effective in emulsifying fats. The conjugation process enhances the solubility and functionality of bile acids in the aqueous environment of the digestive tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycine and alanine: Alanine is not involved in the conjugation of bile acids.

 

Option C. Histidine and glycine: Histidine is not used for conjugation with bile acids.

 

Option D. Glutamic acid and valine: Neither glutamic acid nor valine are involved in bile acid conjugation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycine and taurine are the amino acids conjugated to the steroid nucleus of bile acids, forming bile salts.

questions.text: Transport of glucose on contraluminal side of intestinal cell is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GLUT-2

 

GLUT-2 is involved in the transport of glucose on the basolateral (contraluminal) side of intestinal epithelial cells. After glucose is absorbed into these cells from the intestinal lumen via SGLT-1, it is then transported out into the bloodstream through GLUT-2. This transporter facilitates the exit of glucose from intestinal cells into the blood, playing a crucial role in postprandial glucose homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT-1: SGLT-1 (Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1) is located on the apical (luminal) side of intestinal epithelial cells. It is responsible for the active transport of glucose into the cell from the intestinal lumen, alongside sodium ions. This is the initial step in intestinal glucose absorption but not involved in the basolateral transport.

 

Option C. GLUT-5: GLUT-5 is a fructose transporter, predominantly found on the apical side of intestinal cells. It is responsible for the uptake of fructose from the intestinal lumen, not glucose transport on the contraluminal side.

 

Option D. GLUT-1: GLUT-1 is widely expressed in many tissues and is responsible for the basal uptake of glucose. It is not specifically involved in the transport of glucose on the contraluminal side of intestinal cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT-2 is a glucose transporter, which is primarily found on the basolateral (contra luminal) side of intestinal cells and is involved in the transport of glucose out of the enterocytes into the bloodstream.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 187

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness, anemia, bony pain & hepatosplenomegaly. A histological picture is shown with cells in bone marrow. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluco-Cerebrosidase

 

The picture show macrophages with typical crumpled tissue paper appearance/ wrinkled appearance that is highly characteristic of Gaucher’s disease (most common lysosomal storage disease). Glucocerebrosides accumulate in reticuloendothelial system due to deficiency of enzyme β-Glucocerebrosidase. These patients have bony pain, pathological fractures, hepatosplenomegaly, but no mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Deficiency of Glucose 6 phosphatase is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD-I) or von Gierke disease. This disorder primarily affects glucose metabolism and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase A: Hexosaminidase A deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, which primarily affects the nervous system and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option D. Beta-Galactosidase: Deficiency of Beta-Galactosidase is associated with GM1 gangliosidosis. This lysosomal storage disorder primarily affects the nervous system and is not typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluco-Cerebrosidase, is associated with Gaucher's disease, a rare inherited metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucosylceramide due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. Gaucher's disease can lead to the symptoms described, including hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and bony pain.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 235

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Folate therapy using the B12 stores

 

This is the most likely cause. Folate and vitamin B12 (cobalamin) are interconnected in various metabolic pathways. Folate supplementation can correct the hematologic manifestations of a B12 deficiency, but it does not address the neurologic manifestations. In some cases, folate therapy can "mask" the anemia associated with B12 deficiency, potentially aggravating the neurologic symptoms. The correct approach is to identify and treat the underlying B12 deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malabsorption of folate: Malabsorption of folate could lead to a deficiency, but in this case, the patient was given folate (B9) supplementation, and the blood picture improved. This suggests that the issue is not with the absorption of folate but with its utilization.

 

Option B. Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency: While this is a consideration, especially in cases of neuropathy, the patient's symptoms worsening after folate supplementation suggest another mechanism.

 

Option C. Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS: This is not a recognized mechanism. Folate reductase is an enzyme that converts folate to its active form, and CNS deficiency of this enzyme is not a common cause of neurologic manifestations in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage.

 

The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores, aggravating the symptoms.

 

Administration of folic acid for patients with macrocytic anemia can partially reverse the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe muscle cramps, constipation, and ECG changes showing prolonged QT interval. Daily dietary analysis reveals adequate calcium intake but deficiency of another element essential for neuromuscular function. Which of the following mineral deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Magnesium

 

Explanation: 

 

Magnesium is the correct answer. Although like calcium it's a macromineral (>100 mg/day requirement), magnesium deficiency presents with:

  • Neuromuscular manifestations (cramps, tetany)
  • Cardiac conduction abnormalities (prolonged QT)
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms (constipation)
  • Muscle weakness
  • Irritability and confusion in severe cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Copper is a micronutrient (<100 mg/day). Its deficiency primarily affects hematopoiesis and can cause anemia. It doesn't typically cause the presenting symptoms.

 

Option C. Chromium: Chromium is a trace element. Its deficiency mainly affects glucose metabolism and insulin function, not neuromuscular or cardiac function.

 

Option D. Iodine: Iodine is a micronutrient essential for thyroid hormone synthesis. Deficiency causes goiter and hypothyroidism but doesn't directly cause acute neuromuscular symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Students should understand:

  1. Classification of minerals based on daily requirements: 
    • Macrominerals (>100 mg/day): Ca, P, Na, K, Cl, Mg, S
    • Microminerals (<100 mg/day): Fe, Fl, Cu, Co, Cr, Mn, Mo, Zn, I, Se
  2. Clinical manifestations of magnesium deficiency
  3. Role of magnesium in: 
    • Neuromuscular function
    • Cardiac conduction
    • Enzyme cofactor
    • ATP metabolism
  4. Importance of distinguishing between macro and micromineral deficiencies in clinical presentations

questions.text: Reason of Hepatomegaly in Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of glycogen

 

The reason for hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) in this disease is the accumulation of glycogen. Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. When there is a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, the normal breakdown of glycogen into glucose is impaired, leading to the accumulation of glycogen within the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Accumulation of Glucose-6-phosphate: While glucose-6-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis, its accumulation is not the primary cause of hepatomegaly in glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. Increased Glu-6-P however causes other C/f such as Hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia and Lactic acidosis.

 

Option C. Accumulation of Glucose-1-phosphate: Glucose-1-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis. It does not accumulate in Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option D. Accumulation of glycogenin: Glycogenin is a protein that plays a role in initiating glycogen synthesis, not breakdown. Accumulation of glycogenin is not a typical feature of glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.

questions.text: The following graph is most likely to be seen in: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Non-competitive inhibition

 

 In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to the enzyme at a site other than the active site (allosteric site), changing the enzyme's shape and function. This binding reduces the enzyme's activity regardless of the concentration of the substrate. The Vmax (maximum rate of reaction) decreases, but the Km (substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax) remains the same.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Competitive Inhibition: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site of the enzyme. As a result, increasing the substrate concentration can overcome the inhibition. This type of inhibition increases the apparent Km (as more substrate is needed to reach the half-maximal enzyme activity), but the Vmax remains unchanged.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive Inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the enzyme alone. This leads to a decrease in both Vmax and Km. This type of inhibition is unique in that the inhibitor does not affect the binding of the substrate but inhibits subsequent reaction steps.

 

Option D. Allosteric Inhibition: Allosteric inhibitors bind to a site other than the active site, causing a conformational change in the enzyme that reduces its activity. This type of inhibition does not follow the typical Michaelis-Menten kinetics and cannot be classified purely based on changes in Vmax or Km.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Features of Non-competitive Inhibition

 

  • The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, other than the substrate binding site and the inhibitor has no structural resemblance to substrate and hence, excess substrate does not abolish the inhibition.
  • The inhibitor combines with the enzymes by a covalent bond, which makes the reaction irreversible.
  • The velocity (Vmax) is reduced and the Km value is not changed, because the remaining enzyme molecules have the same affinity for the substrate.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 80-81

questions.text: Vitamin C cannot be produced in humans due to lack of? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-gulonolactone oxidase

 

Most animals and plants can synthesize ascorbic acid from glucose. Man, higher primates, guineapigs and bats are the only species which cannot synthesize ascorbic acid (block in gulonolactone oxidase step). They lack the genes responsible for the synthesis of this enzyme.

 

Details of L-gulonolactone Oxidase:

  • Role: This enzyme is responsible for converting L-gulonolactone to ascorbic acid (vitamin C).
  • Deficiency: Humans, higher primates, guinea pigs, and certain other species lack this enzyme due to mutations or absence of the gene encoding it, which blocks the synthesis of ascorbic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Xylitol reductase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of xylitol to xylulose but is not related to the synthesis of vitamin C.

 

Option C. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: This enzyme complex plays a critical role in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration but is not involved in vitamin C synthesis.

 

Option D. UDP glucose dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of UDP-glucuronic acid from UDP-glucose but has no role in vitamin C production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Humans cannot synthesize vitamin C due to the lack of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase, which is necessary for the final step in the biosynthetic pathway of ascorbic acid from glucose.
